Nick,

Thank you for an excellent contribution. As it happens, Steve Bjorg
and I have been having an off-list discussion around exactly the
question of neutrality / genericity with regards to Atom (a discussion
that has not yet concluded) and your comments provide an excellent
frame for further thinking about the subject imho.

Alan

On Fri, Nov 21, 2008 at 4:16 AM, Nick Gall <nick.gall@...> wrote:
> On Thu, Nov 20, 2008 at 6:40 PM, Subbu Allamaraju <subbu@...> wrote:
>> Since APP is just an application of HTTP to the Atom Syndication Format,
>> is this about using an application neutral payload format for
>> representations? If so, would you call SOAP (the envelope format)
>> application neutral?
>
> The note discusses all 3 facets of an interface: Identifiers, Formats
> (representations), and Protocol operations (IFaPs as we call them). All
> three facets should be as "application neutral" or generic as possible.
> Everyone focuses on generic protocol operations (HTTP's GPPD), but
> generalizing identifiers and formats is equally important.
> SOAP is indeed application neutral. Perhaps even more application neutral
> than HTTP itself, since SOAP is little more than a framework for an XML
> envelope with completely open ended XML header processing. It is extremely
> application neutral. The problem is, interface designers take the incredibly
> generic SOAP format and put an incredibly application specific XML payload
> inside it. That's like stepping of a neutrality cliff -- from extremely
> generic to extremely specific in one step.
> Of course the same can happen (and does happen) with Atom entities or even
> with representations returned by HTTP itself. But it seems to us that
> interface designers in the REST "camp" seem to better understand the
> importance of reusing existing representations for new applications, not
> custom designing representations for each new application. An example of
> this is the RESTafarian insistence that HTTP is NOT a transport protocol,
> but rather an "application protocol", albeit a VERY application neutral one.
> What we haven't seen yet, even from the REST "camp" is much in the way of
> fairly generic ATOM entities to go inside the ATOM "envelope". Many REST
> examples using ATOM step off the same cliff.
> One last point about SOAP. In the note, we make the distinction between
> "application neutrality" and "implementation neutrality". WS-* (and SOAP in
> particular) seems overly focused on "implementation neutrality", ie making
> sure the SOAP envelope and SOAP headers can be bound to virtually any
> underlying middleware (incl. security middleware) technology. In general,
> this emphasis on "implementation neutrality" distracts WS-* interface
> designers from the far more important issue of "application neutrality". In
> fact, SOAP is positioned as simply part of a WS-* "application protocol
> toolkit" to enable developers to design custom application protocols. (I
> have an excerpt from the note about this in my blog post that I gave earlier
> in the thread.)
> -- Nick
